article.title: Microfluidics-enabled method to identify modes of Caenorhabditis elegans paralysis in four anthelmintics
article.abstract: The discovery of new drugs is often propelled by the increasing resistance of parasites to existing drugs and the availability of better technology platforms.

sections.introduction: Parasitic nematodes have adopted a range of infection, survival, and propagation strategies within hosts of interest, including humans, domestic animals (e.g., cows, pigs, sheep, horses), and agricultural plants (e.g., soybean, corn, rice, potato).
sections.methods: The microfluidic device is fabricated using soft lithography.
sections.results: We found that a single parameter was unable to capture the overall drug effects through the experimental period.
sections.discussion: Some modifications were made in our device design and methodology to simplify the earlier experimental method and optimize it for observing events leading to worm paralysis.

article.insights_summary: We presented a method to characterize the behavioral events of C. elegans over an extended time period: from exposure to the drug to their eventual paralysis.
article.acknowledgments: We are grateful to Jo Anne Powell-Coffman for providing C. elegans culture plates, and Alan P. Robertson and Richard Martin for providing the anthelmintics.
